awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Novel Control for Invasive Species -- Modeling, Analysis, and Experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
The effect of invasive species is thought to be second only to habitat destruction as a threat to biodiversity. The spread of invasive species is a major problem in spatial ecology, and there is a large body of literature on understanding this spread. However, there is far less work on the actual eradication and control of invasive species once invasion has occurred. Currently, there are only a few conclusive eradication measures for aquatic invasive species. The Trojan Y-Chromosome (TYC) strategy is an eradication strategy with the advantage of targeting only the invasive species in question, while protecting native species. The PIs will develop an experimentally tested mathematical model of the TYC strategy. The computational and theoretical analysis of the mathematical model will inform experimental biologists about the viability of the TYC strategy and provide crucial insight into the spatial-temporal population dynamics associated with the TYC strategy and other phenomena associated with such control efforts. Ultimately results of the project will guide experimental research at the USGS Wetland and Aquatic Research Center in Gainesville, Florida.

The TYC strategy is a biological control that introduces a sub-population of genetically modified males with YY chromosomes in order that their offspring are guaranteed to be male. The object of the introduction is to skew the sex ratio in the invasive population to be strongly male biased, driving down the female population density, and ultimately leading to extinction. In developing Peocilia reticulata (guppy fish) YY-males in the laboratory, mesocosm experiments can be conducted that examine the interaction, dynamics, fecundity, and viability of the TYC strategy. The experimental data will then be used to develop the relevant parameter space and refine, verify, and validate reaction diffusion models of the TYC strategy. In addition, numerical designs and implementation procedures will be developed to provide a reliable platform to efficiently simulate the system of partial differential equations that incorporate features such as cross and self-diffusion, non-smooth initial datum, temperature effects and life history traits such as cannibalism. This research and its results will advance our understanding of the use of flexible and reversible passive efforts to eradicate and control invasive species, as modeled via both weakly coupled and strongly coupled reaction diffusion systems.

por.por_cntn:
This interdisciplinary research fostered research between applied mathematicians, biologists, and ecologists to study invasive species controls of aquatic species.  Our research focused on three areas:

  1.  Systematically creating and subsequently refining mathematical models of eradication efforts of aquatic invasions, in particular the Trojan Y chromosome eradication strategy;
  2. Incorporation of mesocosm experimental data to drive and inform mathematical modeling designs; and
  3. Mentoring and training of undergraduate and graduate students through interdisciplinary and collaborative research in mathematical biology.

The Trojan Y Chromosome (TYC) strategy is to introduce sex-reversed males to an invasive species population such that mating would yield only wild-type males. The introduction distorts the ratio between female to male off-spring, which cause a population decline. Our research focused on analyzing previously published mathematical models that approximates the populations of female, male, and sex-reversed males. Our research demonstrated unrealistic behavior in the approximated populations. In particular, the predicted populations could become negative in finite time and even lead to finite-time blow up of the population size. This is evident of critical flaws in the mathematical model. Therefore, our research revised and developed new mathematical models that removed such flaws.  This included incorporation of Intraspecies competition for mates and fitness of the overall population due to the Allee effect.  Through the tools of optimal control, we developed optimal introduction rates of sex-reversed males. 

Three significant mesocosm experiments were collaboratively designed and implemented by our research team and the USGS Aquatics and Wetland research laboratory in Gainesville, Florida.  First, the mathematical models required information on the relative birth and death rates of targeted species. Hence, an experiment was developed to provide benchmark rates for guppy fish.  Second, we experimentally studied the effect of environmental pressures on juvenile fish. Specifically, the goal of the experiment was to understand how varying the availability of food for adult and juvenile fish by gender influences the death of the juvenile population. Lastly, we established experiments that emulated the TYC dynamic through harvesting of juvenile females and replaced with juvenile males.  This experiment provided a cost-effective way of emulating the TYC dynamic of distorting the female-male sex ratio in a population.  This experiment motivated alternative mathematical models of TYC that couched TYC as harvesting within an age-stratified model.

This research provided support from 12 undergraduate and 5 graduate students throughout its duration. All students presented research at national and regional conferences. All significantly contributed to the dissemination of related research papers.

 


Last Modified: 12/12/2022
Modified by: Matthew A Beauregard
